comments:
After changing the Plugins we are developing in to pure 3.0 plugins, the
dependancies on plugins in our workspace are no longer resolved. The Eclipse
plugins view will no longer come display. It says "An error has occurred when
creating this view". At this point the workspace is so screwed up starting over
form a new workspace is all that seem sto resolve the problems.
Steps to Reproduce:

We synced up to chages in our CVS repository. 
The ONLY changes were in the plugin.xml files. The plugins were recreated fully
3.0 using the PDE wizard. The differances in the plugin.xml are like this:
ORIGINAL:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<?eclipse version="3.0"?>
<plugin
   id="com.p.commons"
   name="Commons Plug-in"
   version="6.0.0.0"
   provider-name="P Systems">

   <runtime>
      <library name="commons.jar">
         <export name="*"/>
      </library>
   </runtime>
   <requires>
      <import plugin="com.p.eclipse.thirdparty"/>
   </requires>
</plugin>

NEW FILE
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<?eclipse version="3.0"?>
<plugin>
   <runtime>
      <library name="commons.jar">
         <export name="*"/>
      </library>
   </runtime>
   <requires>
      <import plugin="com.p.eclipse.thirdparty"/>
   </requires>
</plugin>

I'm not sure I understand.

what did you do/use to go from the ORIGINAL to the NEW file?
The "NEW" file contains no id, and that is what is causing the problem.  Did 
you remove it yourself?  did some wizard automatically remove it?

Also, please never modify the priority field of bug reports.

No. The wizard does not create one to start with. All of that information is
stored in the Manifest.mf. If you start from nothing and create a new plugin
using the wizard. In the 3.0 plugin structure the plugin.xml looks like this.
There is never any attributes for the node <plugin/>:
NEW FILE
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<?eclipse version="3.0"?>
<plugin>
   <runtime>
      <library name="commons.jar">
         <export name="*"/>
      </library>
   </runtime>
   <requires>
      <import plugin="com.p.eclipse.thirdparty"/>
   </requires>
</plugin>

Sorry, the Manifest does not store the ID either in my recent tests. All other
info is stored there though.

In 3.0, you have the "option" to create a plugin with or without a 
manifest.mf.  Either way is "equally" fine.  

When your plugin contains both a plugin.xml AND a manifest.mf, then the 
plugin.xml contains ONLY extensions/extension points.  All other info (id, 
version, dependencies, etc.) are read exclusively from the manifest.mf.

The NEW file that you have pasted looks suspicious as it contains a <requires> 
element.  You must have added that yourself.  Make sure dependencies are 
declared in the manifest.mf, and not in the plugin.xml.

I therefore suggest you use the PDE editor to edit your 
plugin.xml/manifest.mf, as PDE will automatically write the info to the 
correct files.

It also appears that one of your plugins have a badly formatted version 
number, which is causing this exception.
All the more reason to use the PDE editor, since the parser of the manifest.mf 
is very strict and an extra space here and there can render things invalid.

I have done exactly as you describe. Selecting the option to create the

on the other. However. Neither plugin shows up in the list of plugins when

yes, Bundle-SymbolicName is equivalent to id.

dependencies page of the editor.

Ok so I closed all projects in my workspace and only have the 2 new plugins.
This seems to fix several problems. I guess your comment about a bad id in one
of the plugins needs investigation in our CVS repository. We have MANY btw.
However, It would seem there is still a mix of 2.x and 3.0 info stored in the
plugin.xml even after using the PDE upgrade wizard. This is also true for using
the Plugin wizards. It would be helpful if the PDE upgrade wizard removed all
irrelevant nodes when upgrading. As a rule we already found/know that you cannot
manually edit these files with any margin of safety. 

Something is still screwed up with the plugins but we have not determined that
yet. Thanks for your patience.

Just to be clear about one more thing:
A 3.0 plug-in does NOT mean that you have to have a manifest.mf.

Most 3.0 plug-ins including many in Eclipse don't have a manifest.mf.
Going through the 3.0 migration wizard will:
1. tag your plugin.xml with the <?eclipse ..> processing instruction.
2. modify your plugin dependencies, if necessary, to reflect the platform 
plugin restructuring in 3.0.

That is all you need to function in a 3.0 environment.  You do not need a 
manifest.mf.  The 3.0 migration wizard does not create a manifest.mf.

Bundle tooling has come a long way since this report was open.  the main issue 
here (i.e the IAE has now been resolved).
